information_requirement: Is an adversary attempting to discover the location of our subscribers by impersonating SS7 nodes? (PIR)

evidence.description: An external, non-partner Global Title (GT) is sending location-related queries (e.g., Send Routing Information for SM - SRI-SM) to our Home Location Register (HLR).
evidence.nai: SS7 Signaling Gateways, Home Location Register (HLR)
evidence.action: Maintain a whitelist of all known, legitimate partner Global Titles. Monitor SGW and HLR transaction logs for incoming SS7 MAP messages, specifically location queries like SRI-SM or Provide Subscriber Information (PSI). Generate a high-priority alert for any such query originating from a source GT not present on the partner whitelist. Use descriptive statistics to identify GTs with an anomalously low ratio of other legitimate traffic types vs. location queries.

evidence.description: A single source GT sends an unusually high volume of location queries for many distinct subscribers in a short period, indicating a broad discovery attempt.
evidence.nai: SS7 Signaling Gateways, Home Location Register (HLR)
evidence.action: For each source GT, calculate the rate of location queries per hour and the count of unique target subscribers (MSISDNs) queried. Establish a baseline for normal query rates and unique subscriber counts from legitimate partners. Use statistical methods (e.g., a Z-score greater than 3 or exceeding the 99th percentile) to detect significant deviations from this baseline. A single GT with a high query rate across a high number of unique MSISDNs is a strong indicator of a malicious scan.

information_requirement: Is an adversary successfully collecting subscriber location data via SS7 network exploitation? (PIR)

evidence.description: A pattern of sequential location queries for the same subscriber (MSISDN) originates from an external GT over a short period, suggesting an attempt to track the target's movement.
evidence.nai: Home Location Register (HLR), Visitor Location Register (VLR)
evidence.action: For each unique target subscriber (MSISDN), perform a time-series analysis on incoming location queries. Identify instances where the same MSISDN is queried multiple times (e.g., > 3 times in an hour) from the same anomalous or non-whitelisted source GT. A repeating pattern of queries for a specific subscriber is a strong indicator of active tracking and collection.

evidence.description: Successful location query responses (e.g., SRI-SM ACK containing the serving MSC/VLR address) are sent to a non-whitelisted or suspicious external GT.
evidence.nai: SS7 Signaling Gateways, Home Location Register (HLR)
evidence.action: In HLR or SGW logs, correlate incoming location queries with their corresponding outgoing responses. Filter for successful responses that contain subscriber location information (e.g., serving network node addresses). Create a high-severity alert if a successful response is sent to a GT that is not on the established partner whitelist or has been previously flagged by other detection actions. Calculate the ratio of successful to failed location queries for each external GT; a high success rate from a suspicious source indicates a successful collection campaign.
